laws.summary: Georgia enforces non-compete agreements. O.C.G.A. § 34-2-2 provides statutory framework. Non-compete must be reasonable in time (typically 2-3 years), geography, and scope. Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information, substantial business relationship). Consideration required for existing employees. Georgia is employer-friendly on non-competes; courts will blue-pencil unreasonable provisions.
requirements: NON-COMPETE MUST BE REASONABLE: Time, Territory (geographic scope), Line of Business restricted
LEGITIMATE BUSINESS INTEREST: Trade secrets, substantial relationships with prospective/existing customers, confidential business information, substantial relationships of trust
TIME: Generally 1-3 years reasonable; longer periods require justification; court applies reasonableness test
TERRITORY: Must be limited to area where employer conducted business or had legitimate business interest
SCOPE: Cannot be broader than necessary to protect legitimate interest
CONSIDERATION: New employees: employment is consideration; Existing employees: must receive additional consideration (salary increase, promotion, or other benefit)
WRITTEN AGREEMENT required
NOT ENFORCEABLE: Against employee at-will if no additional consideration for existing employees
BLUE-PENCIL: Georgia courts will modify overly broad provisions to reasonable scope (employer-friendly)
HEALTHCARE: Healthcare providers subject to reasonableness standard; must show protectable relationships
CUSTOMER LIST: Non-competition regarding customer list enforceable if legitimate interest and reasonable
Covenant of good faith: Implied in all employment contracts; cannot be violated
Liquidated damages: Reasonable damages clauses enforceable; must not be penalty
SOLICITATION: Non-solicitation agreements similarly enforceable under reasonableness test
laws.effective_date: O.C.G.A. § 34-2-2 ongoing; common law development ongoing
laws.notes: Georgia is very employer-friendly on non-competes. Courts will modify unreasonable provisions rather than void them. Strong protection for legitimate business interests.

laws.summary: Georgia does NOT have statewide salary history ban. Employers may inquire about and consider past compensation. Federal equal pay principles apply (cannot use to justify discriminatory gaps). No local ordinances in major Georgia cities (Atlanta, etc.) currently ban salary history. Growing national trend but not yet adopted in Georgia.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Equal Pay Act (29 U.S.C. § 206(d)); Title VII (42 U.S.C. § 2000e); Georgia Code lacks specific ban
requirements: NO STATE SALARY HISTORY BAN in Georgia
Employers may inquire about compensation history
Employers may consider prior salary in hiring decisions
Federal Equal Pay Act: Cannot use salary history to justify pay discrimination based on sex
Must pay equal for equal work regardless of prior compensation
Cannot discriminate on basis of protected class using salary history as pretext
Documentation required for all pay decisions
Retaliation prohibited if employee discusses wages
Recommendations: Establish role-based pay scales; document pay decisions; ensure no discriminatory impact on protected classes
laws.effective_date: Federal law ongoing; Georgia has no state law change
laws.notes: Georgia currently permits salary history inquiries at state level. Federal equal pay principles prevent use for discriminatory purposes.

laws.summary: Georgia does NOT require pay transparency in job postings or employee communications at state level. No state-level pay range requirement. Federal contractors subject to pay equity audit requirements (OFCCP). No local ordinances in Atlanta or other major cities. Growing national trend but not yet adopted in Georgia.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Equal Pay Act (29 U.S.C. § 206(d)); Federal OFCCP Rules for Federal Contractors
requirements: NO STATE PAY TRANSPARENCY REQUIREMENT in Georgia
Employers NOT required to disclose salary ranges in job postings
Employers NOT required to provide pay scale to employees at hire/transfer/promotion
Federal contractors: Subject to OFCCP pay equity audit requirements; must maintain pay documentation
Must maintain records of compensation decisions
Federal FLSA: Maintain payroll records
Recommendations: Establish consistent pay scales by job level; maintain documentation; be prepared for federal contractor audits if applicable
laws.effective_date: Federal contractor rules ongoing; Georgia has no state requirement
laws.notes: Georgia lacks state-level pay transparency requirement. Federal contractor compliance required if applicable.

laws.summary: Georgia follows federal FCRA requirements. No state-specific ban-the-box law. Employers may conduct background checks at any time subject to FCRA compliance (written consent, pre-adverse and final adverse action notices). Courts permit background checks if job-related and non-discriminatory. Georgia does not restrict criminal history inquiries.
laws.statute_citation: Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681); Georgia Code § 34-7-2 (limited provisions); Federal ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101)
requirements: FCRA Federal Requirements: Written consent required before background check
FCRA: Pre-adverse action notice (copy of report and FCRA rights) required
FCRA: Final adverse action notice (specific reason) required
FCRA: Third-party vendor must comply with FCRA; accuracy standards apply
NO STATE BAN-THE-BOX LAW statewide in Georgia
Employers may ask about criminal history on application
Employers may conduct background check at any time
Criminal conviction consideration: No specific restrictions; can consider if job-related
Sealed/expunged records: Cannot consider
Arrests without conviction: Cannot use if outside statute of limitations for underlying crime
Juvenile records: Generally cannot consider
ADA CONSIDERATIONS: Cannot discriminate based on disability; background check cannot be pretext for disability discrimination
EEOC GUIDANCE: Background check procedures must not have disparate impact on protected classes
Recommendations: Ensure FCRA-compliant vendor; document job-related business necessity; maintain compliance records
laws.effective_date: FCRA ongoing federal law; Georgia Code ongoing
laws.notes: Georgia follows federal FCRA with no additional state restrictions. Employers have broad latitude for background checks if job-related.

laws.summary: Georgia does NOT mandate paid sick leave or paid family leave for private employers. Federal FMLA applies to employers with 50+ employees. No state-run paid leave program. Private employers free to set own policies. Georgia is not among states with comprehensive paid leave requirements.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Family and Medical Leave Act (29 U.S.C. § 2601 et seq.); No comprehensive Georgia paid leave mandate
requirements: NO STATE PAID SICK LEAVE MANDATE for private employers
NO STATE PAID FAMILY LEAVE MANDATE for private employers
NO STATE-RUN PAID LEAVE PROGRAM
FMLA (Federal): Applies to employers with 50+ employees; covers 12 weeks unpaid leave for FMLA-qualifying reasons
FMLA: Must maintain health insurance; employee restored to same/equivalent position
FMLA: Applies only to employers with 50+ employees
FMLA: Employee must work 12+ months and 1,250 hours in past 12 months
JURY DUTY: Employer cannot penalize for jury service
VOTING: Employer cannot penalize for voting
MILITARY: Federal SCRA applies to military service
WORKERS' COMPENSATION: Cannot penalize for filing claim
Recommendations: Establish voluntary paid leave (beneficial for recruitment); if offering, comply with stated policy; clear documentation
laws.effective_date: Federal FMLA ongoing; Georgia has no state mandate
laws.notes: Georgia lacks state-mandated paid leave. FMLA applies to large employers only (50+). Most Georgia employers not required to provide paid leave.

laws.summary: Georgia enforces arbitration agreements under Federal Arbitration Act (FAA). Must be clear mutual agreement in writing. Courts scrutinize for unconscionability but generally favor arbitration. Class action waivers generally enforceable. No state-specific restrictions on employment arbitration.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. § 1 et seq.); Georgia Uniform Arbitration Act (O.C.G.A. § 34-34-1 et seq.)
requirements: Arbitration agreements enforceable under Federal Arbitration Act
Must be in writing; clearly presented
Must evidence mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be unconscionable (procedurally or substantively)
Must be supported by consideration
Class action waivers generally enforceable if mutual and not unconscionable
Arbitration cannot eliminate statutory rights; must preserve remedies
Costs: Employer generally bears arbitrator/forum fees if employee must bear to access
Federal FAA preemption: Georgia applies FAA; FAA preempts state law
Unconscionability test: Procedural (surprise, unequal bargaining) and substantive (terms unreasonably favorable to employer)
Recommendations: Clear language; mutual obligations; adequate cost allocation; remedy preservation
laws.effective_date: Federal FAA ongoing; Georgia Uniform Arbitration Act ongoing
laws.notes: Georgia enforces arbitration under federal FAA standards with general pro-arbitration stance.

laws.summary: Georgia follows at-will employment doctrine. Either party can terminate for any reason without cause or notice (absent contract/policy creating obligation). Exceptions: cannot terminate for illegal reason (discrimination, retaliation, violation of public policy), cannot breach express/implied contract, cannot breach good faith covenant.
laws.statute_citation: Georgia Common Law; O.C.G.A. § 34-7-2 (Protection Against Employer Retaliation); Federal Laws
requirements: DEFAULT: At-will employment; either party can terminate without cause/notice

EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, sex, national origin, age 40+, disability (ADA), military service (federal), jury duty (federal), voting, workers' compensation claim (O.C.G.A. § 34-9-2), wage claim, whistleblowing (O.C.G.A. § 34-7-2), reporting illegal activity, jury duty participation, voting

WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (O.C.G.A. § 34-7-2): Employee cannot be discharged, threatened, or discriminated against for reporting violation of law to appropriate governmental authority or refusing to participate in unlawful activity
WORKERS' COMPENSATION: Cannot discharge for filing claim
JURY DUTY: Cannot prevent jury service
VOTING: Cannot prevent voting; reasonable time off
MILITARY SERVICE: Federal USERRA applies
PUBLIC POLICY EXCEPTION: Cannot terminate for activity in public interest (e.g., whistleblowing, refusing unlawful act)
IMPLIED CONTRACT: Handbook or conduct may create enforceable contract
GOOD FAITH COVENANT: Implied in all employment; cannot be violated
FINAL PAY: Final wages must be paid timely
AT-WILL DISCLAIMER: Should be clear in handbook; ambiguous language may not override contract implications
Remedies: Breach of contract, wrongful termination, damages
laws.effective_date: Common law ongoing; statutory protections as noted
laws.notes: Georgia at-will employment with exceptions for protected activities and public policy. Handbooks may create enforceable rights.

laws.summary: Georgia allows drug testing under reasonable circumstances. No specific restrictions on pre-employment testing. Post-employment random testing permitted if policy provides. Marijuana (both recreational and medical) NOT legal in Georgia; employers can prohibit and test. Very employer-friendly on drug testing policies.
laws.statute_citation: Georgia law lacks comprehensive drug testing statute; follows common law; Federal Drug-Free Workplace Act (41 U.S.C. § 8101); Federal ADA (42 U.S.C. § 12101)
requirements: PRE-EMPLOYMENT TESTING: Permitted; no state restriction
POST-EMPLOYMENT TESTING: Permitted with reasonable suspicion or random testing if policy provides
MARIJUANA: NOT legal in Georgia (neither recreational nor medical); employers can test and prohibit
TESTING REQUIREMENTS: Written policy recommended; notice to employees; use certified lab (SAMHSA-certified)
CONFIRMATION: Positive screening should be confirmed
FEDERAL CONTRACTORS: Subject to federal drug-free workplace requirements
DOT-REGULATED: DOT testing requirements apply to safety-sensitive positions
REASONABLE SUSPICION: Observable evidence of impairment; document before testing
SAFETY-SENSITIVE POSITIONS: Can enforce stricter testing for public safety positions
PRESCRIBED MEDICATIONS: Cannot test positive for validly prescribed medication; ADA may limit action based on disability
MEDICAL REVIEW OFFICER (MRO): Recommended to review results
Recommendations: Clear written policy; notice to applicants/employees; use certified labs; document reasonable suspicion; maintain confidentiality
laws.effective_date: Ongoing; no significant state law changes affecting drug testing
laws.notes: Georgia very employer-friendly on drug testing. Marijuana not legal. Employers have broad discretion for testing policies.

data_quality.sources: Georgia Code, Georgia Department of Labor, Georgia Courts, Federal EEOC, Legal Databases

additional_notes.general_guidance: Georgia is VERY EMPLOYER-FRIENDLY regarding worker protections. Strong enforcement of non-competes (with blue-pencil modification), no salary history ban, no pay transparency requirement, permissive on background checks, no state-mandated paid leave, and employer-friendly on drug testing. At-will employment with exceptions for protected activities. Marijuana not legal.

No recent significant worker protection expansions
Federal OFCCP audit requirements apply to federal contractors
Georgia maintains employer-friendly stance on employment law
